main_html_content:
• Recipes
  • Recipes By Course
  • Breakfast & Brunch

Baked Eggs With Creamy Greens, Mushrooms, and Cheese Recipe

Leafy greens combine with mushrooms, garlic, leeks, mustard, and spices to form in a baked-egg dish that's a bit like an omelette turned inside out.

By
Emily and Matt Clifton
Emily and Matt Clifton
Emily and Matt Clifton are recipe developers, photographers, and cookbook authors. Their two cookbooks are Cork and Knife (2019) and The Ultimate Dutch Oven Cookbook (2021).
Learn about Serious Eats' Editorial Process
Updated March 14, 2025
WRITE A REVIEW

Why It Works

  • Using three different types of greens creates a blend of textures and flavors in the baked dish.
  • Squeezing the cooked greens well removes excess liquid, preventing a watery dish later.

Three kinds of leafy greens combine with mushrooms, garlic, leeks, mustard, and spices to form the base for a baked-egg dish that's a bit like an omelette turned inside out. It's an ideal recipe for brunch, or really any meal of the day.

Cheesy Baked Eggs, Meet Creamed Spinach (and Kale, and Swiss Chard)

Recipe Details

Baked Eggs With Creamy Greens, Mushrooms, and Cheese Recipe

Prep 10 mins
Cook 50 mins
Active 30 mins
Total 60 mins
Serves 4 to 6 servings
Cook Mode (Keep screen awake)

Ingredients

  • Kosher salt

  • 1 large bunch lacinato kale, tough stems removed, leaves roughly chopped (about 6 ounces; 180 g after stemming)

  • 1 large bunch Swiss chard, tough stems removed, leaves roughly chopped (about 7 ounces; 200 g after stemming)

  • 5 ounces (140 g) baby spinach

  • 3 tablespoons (45 g) unsalted butter, divided

  • 8 ounces (225 g) button or cremini mushrooms, stems trimmed and caps sliced

  • Freshly ground black pepper

  • 2 leeks, white and light green parts only, washed well and thinly sliced (about 9 ounces; 250 g total)

  • 3 medium cloves garlic, 2 minced or grated and 1 left whole for toast, divided

  • 2 tablespoons (45 g) all-purpose flour

  • 1 cup (235 ml) half-and-half

  • 1/2 cup (120 ml) milk

  • 3 tablespoons (45 ml) dry white wine

  • 1/8 teaspoon freshly grated nutmeg

  • 2 teaspoons (10 ml) Dijon mustard

  • 3/4 cup grated Gruyère cheese (2 1/2 ounces; 75 g)

  • 4 to 6 large eggs

  • Pinch of red chile flakes, for garnish

  • 4 to 6 slices toasted and buttered bread, such as from a baguette

Directions

  1. Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C). Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil. Working in batches if necessary, add kale, chard, and spinach to pot and cook for 1 minute. Using a spider or strainer, lift greens from water and transfer to a colander. Immediately run under cold water to stop the cooking. Repeat with remaining greens if necessary. Using your hands, squeeze greens to remove as much excess liquid as possible. Roughly chop greens and set aside. You should have about 10 1/2 ounces (300g) of cooked, squeezed greens.

  2. In a large skillet, melt 1 tablespoon (15g) butter over medium-high heat until foaming. Add mushrooms and cook, stirring only occasionally, until well browned, about 6 minutes. Season with salt and pepper, then transfer to a plate.

  3. Add remaining 2 tablespoons (30g) butter to skillet and melt over medium-high heat until foaming. Add leeks and cook, stirring often, until softened but not browned. Stir in minced garlic and cook 30 seconds. Sprinkle flour over leeks and cook, stirring, until raw flour smell has cooked off, about 1 minute. Stir in half and half and milk. Bring to a simmer and cook until sauce thickens, 1 to 2 minutes. Stir in wine, nutmeg, mustard, reserved mushrooms, and reserved greens and return to a simmer. Season with salt and pepper. Remove skillet from heat. If mixture is very thick, add a bit more water or milk to thin slightly (this will depend on how much water you squeezed out of the greens). You should have about 4 cups of creamed greens.

  4. If baking in the same skillet, sprinkle Gruyère on top of greens. (You can also divide greens into smaller individual skillets or baking dishes.) If using a baking dish, scrape creamy greens into it, smooth into an even layer, and sprinkle Gruyère on top.

  5. Using a spoon, make egg-sized indentations in greens, one for each egg. Crack an egg into each well and season with salt. Bake until egg whites are just set and yolks are still runny, 10 to 20 minutes. Check eggs frequently to make sure they don’t overcook. Remove from oven and sprinkle a pinch of red chili flakes over each egg.

  6. While toast is still warm, gently rub one side of each slice with remaining clove of garlic. Serve, using toast to scoop up greens and eggs.

Special equipment

Baking dish or large ovenproof skillet

This Recipe Appears In

  • Cheesy Baked Eggs, Meet Creamed Spinach (and Kale, and Swiss Chard)
  • Vegetarian Breakfast & Brunch
  • Savory
  • Gruyere
  • Baked Eggs
  • Greens

review.reviewBody:
I made this and it was lovely. Adding it to the rotation of recipes. 
I did make a few adjustments (1) I did not have time to boil the greens, so I merely cooked them in the pan for longer, and (2) substituted leeks for green onions as that's what I had available.
I made this tonight for dinner. I followed the recipe as written. Fantastic! We all loved it. Added surprise, my two year old loved it as well. I will be making this again. Thanks for a great recipe.

Looks cool - I wonder how well the recipe would handle freezing.

Any thoughts on how this would handle being made up through step 4, portioned into individual ramekins and frozen? Then you could pre-make a bunch, thaw one in the fridge overnight, crack an egg, and bake for easy weekday morning yumminess!

-P

some days ago I made a combo of leeks, cabbage, eggs and topped it with mustard.
DAMN that was good!

Even easier way to have creamed greens (spinach, chard, kale): chiffonade them medium, strew half in a bowl (size on which a microwave cover will fit), added mixed grated cheeses of choice with perhaps a knob of butter, cover and cook on the reheat sensor function until done. Stir. No water or roux or thickener needed. Simple. Can top with eggs and toppings of choice.
